speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: SCENE III. Bosworth Field.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD III in arms, with NORFOLK, SURREY, and others

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Here pitch our tents, even here in Bosworth field.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?

speaker: SURREY
text_entry: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: My Lord of Norfolk,--

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Here, most gracious liege.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Norfolk, we must have knocks; ha! must we not?

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: We must both give and take, my gracious lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Up with my tent there! here will I lie tonight;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: But where to-morrow?  Well, all's one for that.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Who hath descried the number of the foe?

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Why, our battalion trebles that account:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Besides, the king's name is a tower of strength,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Which they upon the adverse party want.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Up with my tent there! Valiant gentlemen,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Let us survey the vantage of the field

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Call for some men of sound direction

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Let's want no discipline, make no delay,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: For, lords, to-morrow is a busy day.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter, on the other side of the field, RICHMOND,  Sir William Brandon, OXFORD, and others. Some of the Soldiers pitch RICHMOND's tent

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The weary sun hath made a golden set,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: And by the bright track of his fiery car,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Gives signal, of a goodly day to-morrow.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Sir William Brandon, you shall bear my standard.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Give me some ink and paper in my tent

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: I'll draw the form and model of our battle,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Limit each leader to his several charge,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: And part in just proportion our small strength.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The Earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Good Captain Blunt, bear my good night to him

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: And by the second hour in the morning

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Desire the earl to see me in my tent:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Yet one thing more, good Blunt, before thou go'st,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Where is Lord Stanley quarter'd, dost thou know?

speaker: BLUNT
text_entry: Unless I have mista'en his colours much,

speaker: BLUNT
text_entry: Which well I am assured I have not done,

speaker: BLUNT
text_entry: His regiment lies half a mile at least

speaker: BLUNT
text_entry: South from the mighty power of the king.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: If without peril it be possible,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Good Captain Blunt, bear my good-night to him,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: And give him from me this most needful scroll.

speaker: BLUNT
text_entry: Upon my life, my lord, I'll under-take it;

speaker: BLUNT
text_entry: And so, God give you quiet rest to-night!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Good night, good Captain Blunt. Come gentlemen,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Let us consult upon to-morrow's business

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: In to our tent; the air is raw and cold.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: They withdraw into the tent

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Enter, to his tent, KING RICHARD III, NORFOLK, RATCLIFF, CATESBY, and others

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What is't o'clock?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: It's supper-time, my lord;

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: It's nine o'clock.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I will not sup to-night.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Give me some ink and paper.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What, is my beaver easier than it was?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And all my armour laid into my tent?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: If is, my liege; and all things are in readiness.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Use careful watch, choose trusty sentinels.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: I go, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Stir with the lark to-morrow, gentle Norfolk.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: I warrant you, my lord.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Catesby!

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Send out a pursuivant at arms

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Before sunrising, lest his son George fall

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Into the blind cave of eternal night.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exit CATESBY

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Ratcliff!

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Thomas the Earl of Surrey, and himself,

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Much about cock-shut time, from troop to troop

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Went through the army, cheering up the soldiers.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I have not that alacrity of spirit,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Nor cheer of mind, that I was wont to have.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Set it down. Is ink and paper ready?

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: It is, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Bid my guard watch; leave me.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Ratcliff, about the mid of night come to my tent

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And help to arm me. Leave me, I say.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exeunt RATCLIFF and the other Attendants

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter DERBY to RICHMOND in his tent, Lords and others attending

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: All comfort that the dark night can afford

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Be to thy person, noble father-in-law!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Tell me, how fares our loving mother?

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Who prays continually for Richmond's good:

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: So much for that. The silent hours steal on,

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: And flaky darkness breaks within the east.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: In brief,--for so the season bids us be,--

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Prepare thy battle early in the morning,

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: And put thy fortune to the arbitrement

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: I, as I may--that which I would I cannot,--

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: With best advantage will deceive the time,

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms:

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: But on thy side I may not be too forward

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George,

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Be executed in his father's sight.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Farewell: the leisure and the fearful time

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: And ample interchange of sweet discourse,

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Which so long sunder'd friends should dwell upon:

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: God give us leisure for these rites of love!

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Once more, adieu: be valiant, and speed well!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Good lords, conduct him to his regiment:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: I'll strive, with troubled thoughts, to take a nap,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Lest leaden slumber peise me down to-morrow,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: When I should mount with wings of victory:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Exeunt all but RICHMOND

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: O Thou, whose captain I account myself,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Look on my forces with a gracious eye;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: That they may crush down with a heavy fall

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The usurping helmets of our adversaries!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Make us thy ministers of chastisement,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: That we may praise thee in the victory!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: To thee I do commend my watchful soul,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Sleeps

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of Prince Edward, son to King Henry VI

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Ghost

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: Let me sit heavy on thy soul to-morrow!

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: Think, how thou stab'dst me in my prime of youth

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: At Tewksbury: despair, therefore, and die!

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: To RICHMOND

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: Be cheerful, Richmond; for the wronged souls

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: Of butcher'd princes fight in thy behalf

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: King Henry's issue, Richmond, comforts thee.

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of King Henry VI

speaker: of Prince Edward
text_entry: Ghost

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: When I was mortal, my anointed body

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: By thee was punched full of deadly holes

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: Think on the Tower and me: despair, and die!

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: Harry the Sixth bids thee despair, and die!

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: To RICHMOND

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: Virtuous and holy, be thou conqueror!

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: Harry, that prophesied thou shouldst be king,

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: Doth comfort thee in thy sleep: live, and flourish!

speaker: of King Henry VI
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of CLARENCE

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: Let me sit heavy on thy soul to-morrow!

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: I, that was wash'd to death with fulsome wine,

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: Poor Clarence, by thy guile betrayed to death!

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: To-morrow in the battle think on me,

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: And fall thy edgeless sword: despair, and die!--

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: To RICHMOND

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: Thou offspring of the house of Lancaster

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: The wronged heirs of York do pray for thee

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: Good angels guard thy battle! live, and flourish!

speaker: Ghost of CLARENCE
text_entry: Enter the Ghosts of RIVERS, GRAY, and VAUGHAN

speaker: Ghost of RIVERS
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: Ghost of RIVERS
text_entry: Let me sit heavy on thy soul to-morrow,

speaker: Ghost of RIVERS
text_entry: Rivers. that died at Pomfret! despair, and die!

speaker: Ghost of GREY
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: Ghost of GREY
text_entry: Think upon Grey, and let thy soul despair!

speaker: Ghost of VAUGHAN
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: Ghost of VAUGHAN
text_entry: Think upon Vaughan, and, with guilty fear,

speaker: Ghost of VAUGHAN
text_entry: Let fall thy lance: despair, and die!

speaker: All
text_entry: [To RICHMOND]

speaker: All
text_entry: Awake, and think our wrongs in Richard's bosom

speaker: All
text_entry: Will conquer him! awake, and win the day!

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of HASTINGS

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: Bloody and guilty, guiltily awake,

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: And in a bloody battle end thy days!

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: Think on Lord Hastings: despair, and die!

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: To RICHMOND

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: Quiet untroubled soul, awake, awake!

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: Arm, fight, and conquer, for fair England's sake!

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter the Ghosts of the two young Princes

speaker: Ghost of HASTINGS
text_entry: Ghosts

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Dream on thy cousins smother'd in the Tower:

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Let us be led within thy bosom, Richard,

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: And weigh thee down to ruin, shame, and death!

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Thy nephews' souls bid thee despair and die!

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: To RICHMOND

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Sleep, Richmond, sleep in peace, and wake in joy;

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Good angels guard thee from the boar's annoy!

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Live, and beget a happy race of kings!

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Edward's unhappy sons do bid thee flourish.

speaker: of young Princes
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of LADY ANNE

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: Richard, thy wife, that wretched Anne thy wife,

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: That never slept a quiet hour with thee,

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: Now fills thy sleep with perturbations

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: To-morrow in the battle think on me,

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: And fall thy edgeless sword: despair, and die!

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: To RICHMOND

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thou quiet soul, sleep thou a quiet sleep

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: Dream of success and happy victory!

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thy adversary's wife doth pray for thee.

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of BUCKINGHAM

speaker: Ghost of LADY ANNE
text_entry: Ghost

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: [To KING RICHARD III]

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The last was I that helped thee to the crown;

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The last was I that felt thy tyranny:

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: O, in the battle think on Buckingham,

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And die in terror of thy guiltiness!

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death:

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Fainting, despair; despairing, yield thy breath!

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To RICHMOND

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I died for hope ere I could lend thee aid:

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But cheer thy heart, and be thou not dismay'd:

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: God and good angel fight on Richmond's side;

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And Richard falls in height of all his pride.

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The Ghosts vanish

speaker: of BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: KING RICHARD III starts out of his dream

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Give me another horse: bind up my wounds.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Have mercy, Jesu!--Soft! I did but dream.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The lights burn blue. It is now dead midnight.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What do I fear?  myself?  there's none else by:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Richard loves Richard; that is, I am I.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Is there a murderer here?  No. Yes, I am:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Then fly. What, from myself?   Great reason why:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Lest I revenge. What, myself upon myself?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Alack. I love myself. Wherefore?  for any good

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: That I myself have done unto myself?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: O, no! alas, I rather hate myself

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: For hateful deeds committed by myself!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I am a villain: yet I lie. I am not.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Fool, of thyself speak well: fool, do not flatter.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: My conscience hath a thousand several tongues,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And every tongue brings in a several tale,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And every tale condemns me for a villain.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Perjury, perjury, in the high'st degree

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Murder, stem murder, in the direst degree;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: All several sins, all used in each degree,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Throng to the bar, crying all, Guilty! guilty!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I shall despair. There is no creature loves me;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And if I die, no soul shall pity me:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Nay, wherefore should they, since that I myself

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Find in myself no pity to myself?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Methought the souls of all that I had murder'd

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Came to my tent; and every one did threat

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: To-morrow's vengeance on the head of Richard.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter RATCLIFF

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: My lord!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: 'Zounds! who is there?

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Ratcliff, my lord; 'tis I. The early village-cock

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Hath twice done salutation to the morn;

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Your friends are up, and buckle on their armour.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: O Ratcliff, I have dream'd a fearful dream!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What thinkest thou, will our friends prove all true?

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: No doubt, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: O Ratcliff, I fear, I fear,--

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Nay, good my lord, be not afraid of shadows.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: By the apostle Paul, shadows to-night

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Armed in proof, and led by shallow Richmond.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: It is not yet near day. Come, go with me;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Under our tents I'll play the eaves-dropper,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: To see if any mean to shrink from me.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter the Lords to RICHMOND, sitting in his tent

speaker: LORDS
text_entry: Good morrow, Richmond!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.

speaker: LORDS
text_entry: How have you slept, my lord?

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The sweetest sleep, and fairest-boding dreams

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: That ever enter'd in a drowsy head,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Have I since your departure had, my lords.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Methought their souls, whose bodies Richard murder'd,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Came to my tent, and cried on victory:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: I promise you, my soul is very jocund

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: In the remembrance of so fair a dream.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: How far into the morning is it, lords?

speaker: LORDS
text_entry: Upon the stroke of four.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Why, then 'tis time to arm and give direction.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: His oration to his soldiers

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: More than I have said, loving countrymen,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The leisure and enforcement of the time

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Forbids to dwell upon: yet remember this,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: God and our good cause fight upon our side;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Like high-rear'd bulwarks, stand before our faces;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Richard except, those whom we fight against

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Had rather have us win than him they follow:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: For what is he they follow?  truly, gentlemen,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: A bloody tyrant and a homicide;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: One raised in blood, and one in blood establish'd;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: One that made means to come by what he hath,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: And slaughter'd those that were the means to help him;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Abase foul stone, made precious by the foil

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Of England's chair, where he is falsely set;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: One that hath ever been God's enemy:

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Then, if you fight against God's enemy,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: God will in justice ward you as his soldiers;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: If you do sweat to put a tyrant down,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: If you do fight against your country's foes,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Your country's fat shall pay your pains the hire;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: If you do fight in safeguard of your wives,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: If you do free your children from the sword,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Your children's children quit it in your age.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Then, in the name of God and all these rights,

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Advance your standards, draw your willing swords.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: For me, the ransom of my bold attempt

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Shall be this cold corpse on the earth's cold face;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: But if I thrive, the gain of my attempt

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: The least of you shall share his part thereof.

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Sound drums and trumpets boldly and cheerfully;

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: RICHMOND
text_entry: Re-enter KING RICHARD, RATCLIFF, Attendants and Forces

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: That he was never trained up in arms.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: He said the truth: and what said Surrey then?

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: He smiled and said 'The better for our purpose.'

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: He was in the right; and so indeed it is.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Clock striketh

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Ten the clock there. Give me a calendar.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Who saw the sun to-day?

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Not I, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Then he disdains to shine; for by the book

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: He should have braved the east an hour ago

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliff!

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The sun will not be seen to-day;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I would these dewy tears were from the ground.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Not shine to-day! Why, what is that to me

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: More than to Richmond?  for the selfsame heaven

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter NORFOLK

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Arm, arm, my lord; the foe vaunts in the field.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Come, bustle, bustle; caparison my horse.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Call up Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And thus my battle shall be ordered:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Consisting equally of horse and foot;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Our archers shall be placed in the midst

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: They thus directed, we will follow

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: In the main battle, whose puissance on either side

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: This, and Saint George to boot! What think'st thou, Norfolk?

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: A good direction, warlike sovereign.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: This found I on my tent this morning.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: He sheweth him a paper

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: 'Jockey of Norfolk, be not too bold,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: For Dickon thy master is bought and sold.'

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: A thing devised by the enemy.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Go, gentleman, every man unto his charge

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Let not our babbling dreams affright our souls:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Conscience is but a word that cowards use,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Devised at first to keep the strong in awe:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Our strong arms be our conscience, swords our law.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: March on, join bravely, let us to't pell-mell

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: If not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: His oration to his Army

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What shall I say more than I have inferr'd?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Remember whom you are to cope withal;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: A sort of vagabonds, rascals, and runaways,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: A scum of Bretons, and base lackey peasants,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Whom their o'er-cloyed country vomits forth

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: To desperate ventures and assured destruction.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: You sleeping safe, they bring to you unrest;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: You having lands, and blest with beauteous wives,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: They would restrain the one, distain the other.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And who doth lead them but a paltry fellow,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Long kept in Bretagne at our mother's cost?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: A milk-sop, one that never in his life

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Felt so much cold as over shoes in snow?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Let's whip these stragglers o'er the seas again;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Lash hence these overweening rags of France,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: These famish'd beggars, weary of their lives;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Who, but for dreaming on this fond exploit,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: For want of means, poor rats, had hang'd themselves:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: If we be conquer'd, let men conquer us,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And not these bastard Bretons; whom our fathers

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Have in their own land beaten, bobb'd, and thump'd,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And in record, left them the heirs of shame.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Shall these enjoy our lands?  lie with our wives?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Ravish our daughters?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Drum afar off

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Hark! I hear their drum.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Fight, gentlemen of England! fight, bold yoemen!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Draw, archers, draw your arrows to the head!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Spur your proud horses hard, and ride in blood;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Amaze the welkin with your broken staves!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What says Lord Stanley? will he bring his power?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, he doth deny to come.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Off with his son George's head!

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: After the battle let George Stanley die.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: A thousand hearts are great within my bosom:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Advance our standards, set upon our foes

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Upon them! victory sits on our helms.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exeunt
